column1: Error_Prompts

3 radiographs are provided.  On the film 3, the tip of the Dobbhoff catheter
 projects over the proximal parts of the stomach.  The course of the device is
 unremarkable.  No complications. Unchanged appearance of the lung parenchyma,
 the pleura and the heart.

3 radiographs are provided.  On the film 3, the tip of the Dobbhoff catheter
 projects over the proximal parts of the stomach.  The course of the device is
 unremarkable.  No complications. Unchanged appearance of the lung parenchyma,
 the pleura and the heart.

Interval placement of right-sided catheter with pigtail projecting over the
 liver.  Persistent moderate size right pneumothorax with continued mild
 leftward shift of mediastinal structures.  Patchy atelectasis in both lungs. 
 Increased subcutaneous emphysema in the right lateral chest wall.

Comparison to ___.  Stable mild elevation of the right hemidiaphragm.
 Borderline size of the cardiac silhouette.  Moderate elongation of the
 descending aorta.  The known right pneumothorax has decreased in extent and
 severity, the pneumothorax is now 2 to 4 mm in diameter.  No evidence of
 tension is noted.

COMPARED TO CHEST RADIOGRAPHS ___ through ___.
 
 Small right apical pneumothorax is larger today than on ___.  Pigtail
 pleural drainage catheter unchanged in position projecting over the right
 lower chest.  No appreciable pleural effusion.  Normal cardiomediastinal and
 hilar silhouettes.  Lungs grossly clear.

In comparison with the earlier study of this date, there is no evidence of
 pneumothorax on the right.  Although this was seen on the recent chest CT, it
 may not be appreciated radiographically due to its anterior position. Multiple
 rib fractures are again seen on the right.

Small right apical pneumothorax is minimally larger than it was on ___
 at 6:32 p.m.  There is no hematoma  associated with the displaced right
 posterior rib fractures. Small right pleural effusion seen on the lateral view
 only is unchanged.Mediastinum has a normal appearance.  Lungs are clear.

Small to moderate, right apical pneumothorax and rib fractures are unchanged
 from ___.

Small to moderate, right apical pneumothorax and rib fractures are unchanged
 from ___.

1.  Moderate right apical pneumothorax is mildly increased in size from ___.
 
 2.  Rib fractures are stable.

Moderate bilateral pneumothoraces with increase in size of the left-sided
 pneumothorax compared to prior.

Moderate bilateral pneumothoraces.  The pneumothorax on the right is of
 similar size and the pneumothorax on the left is slightly larger.

Cardiomediastinal silhouette is within normal limits.  There is again seen
 prominence of the mediastinum and of the left suprahilar region consistent
 with known mass.  No pneumomediastinum is identified.  This is better assessed
 on the prior CT scan.  Lungs are grossly clear. There are no pneumothoraces.

The right-sided Swan-___ catheter is in good position.
 
 The intra-aortic balloon pump is approximately 1 cm from the of the aortic
 arch.

Compared to prior chest radiographs ___ through ___.
 
 Small right pleural effusion is substantially smaller.  No pneumothorax. 
 Right basal pigtail drainage catheter in place.  Heart size normal.  Aortic
 graft in place.  No pneumonia.  Stabilization hardware in the upper thoracic
 spine.

Compared to prior chest radiographs ___ through ___.
 
 Small right pleural effusion is substantially smaller.  No pneumothorax. 
 Right basal pigtail drainage catheter in place.  Heart size normal.  Aortic
 graft in place.  No pneumonia.  Stabilization hardware in the upper thoracic
 spine.

Right chest tube is in place (inferior).  The multiple rib fractures and flail
 chest are even more pronounced on the current study than on the previous
 examination as well as acromioclavicular dislocation. Heart size and
 mediastinum are stable.  Left lung is clear.  Apycalthickening on the right is
 unchanged

No relevant change in extent of the known left pneumothorax that still
 measures approximately 1 cm in diameter.  No evidence of tension.  Unchanged
 appearance of the heart and the right lung.  Unchanged position of the left
 chest tube.

As compared to the previous radiograph, the extent of the known left apical
 pneumothorax has substantially increased. The pneumothorax has now a width of
 approximately 2.5 cm. However, there is no sign of tension. Unchanged normal
 size of the cardiac silhouette. No pleural effusions. No pulmonary edema. No
 pneumonia.

Compared to chest radiographs ___ through ___.
 
 New feeding tube, with the wire stylet in place, ends in the upper stomach. 
 Lungs grossly clear.  No pneumothorax or pleural effusion.  Heart size normal.
 Transvenous right atrial right ventricular pacer leads continuous from the
 left pectoral generator.

AP chest compared to ___, 11:53 a.m.:
 
 There has been no change in volume of the small left apical pneumothorax since
 ___:53 a.m., following repair of the left clavicle.  There is no pleural
 effusion.  Heart size is normal.  Stomach is probably significantly distended
 with air and fluid.

In comparison to prior radiograph from earlier the same date, a moderate
 pneumothorax with apical and lateral components has slightly decreased in
 size.  Exam is otherwise remarkable for worsening bibasilar atelectasis, with
 no other relevant change since recent study.

Comparison to ___.  The bilateral chest tubes are in stable position. 
 Massive air inclusions in the soft tissues.  3-4 mm right apical pneumothorax.
 On the left the current image shows no convincing evidence for the presence of
 a pneumothorax.  No evidence of tension.  Normal size of the heart.  No
 pulmonary edema.  No pneumonia.

Interval re-development of large left-sided pneumothorax with
 associated signs of mild rightward mediastinal shift.
 
 Findings were discussed via telephone to Dr. ___ by Dr. ___ at 4:05
 p.m. on ___.

Tracheostomy tube remains in standard position.  Cardiomediastinal contours
 are stable considering markedly leftward patient rotation.  Persistent left
 retrocardiac atelectasis and or consolidation. Multiple pulmonary nodules are
 again demonstrated involving the right lung to a greater degree than the left.
 There is also a probable layering right pleural effusion.

Tracheostomy tube remains in standard position.  Cardiomediastinal contours

 There is also a probable layering right pleural effusion.

Limited study due to patient body habitus and rotation. Persistent left lower
 lobe retrocardiac opacity likely due to collapsed left lower lobe. Multiple
 lung nodules are again demonstrated. Presumed right pleural effusion is
 probably small and unchanged. Lines and tubes are in unchanged position

PA and lateral chest compared to ___:
 
 Previous right lower lobe collapse has substantially, though not entirely
 cleared, and accompanying small right pleural effusion has decreased as well. 
 Multiple right rib fractures are healing.  Heart size is normal.  Left lung is
 clear.

In comparison to ___ chest radiograph, 2 serial radiographs document
 replacement of a nasogastric tube with a feeding tube.  On the second and
 final image of the series, a feeding tube coils within the stomach, with
 distal tip directed cephalad in the fundus.  Exam is otherwise unchanged since
 recent study.

1. New large left pneumothorax with rightward mediastinal shift.
 2. Dobbhoff tube appearing to enter trachea and left mainstem bronchus, with
 diaphragmatic penetration and distal tip projecting over the left mid abdomen.

Large left pneumothorax without signs of tension, increased in
 size dramatically from prior exam.  Findings were posted and flagged to the ED
 dashboard at the time of this dictation.

Comparison to ___.  The aortic balloon pump has been advanced.  The
 tip is now approximately 8 mm from the most apical part of the aortic arch. 
 The other monitoring and support devices are also in correct position. 
 Moderate cardiomegaly persists.  Minimal left pleural effusion.  No pulmonary
 edema.  No pneumonia.

Unchanged position of the ___ tube.  The right internal jugular vein

 and potentially position in the brachiocephalic vein.  Moderate cardiomegaly. 
 Bilateral areas of basilar atelectasis.

1.  Presumed esophageal rupture, with diffuse pneumomediastinum tracking into

Comparison to ___, 09:14.  The left chest tube has been removed. 
 The extent of the known left pneumothorax has slightly increased.  The
 diameter of the pneumothorax is now approximately 2.5 cm.  There is no
 mediastinal shift and no diaphragmatic depression.  Otherwise, the radiograph
 is unchanged.

4 successive frontal views of the chest show advancement of the feeding tube
 with the wire stylet in place from the upper to the mid to the lower esophagus
 and then into the upper stomach. Lungs are clear. Healed rib fractures and
 local pleural thickening should not be mistaken for lung nodules. Normal
 cardiomediastinal silhouette.
